articles.headline: As Iran Picks a President, a Nuclear Shift: Open Talk About Building the Bomb
articles.snippet: Iran has expanded its most sensitive nuclear production site in recent weeks. And for the first time, some leaders are dropping their insistence that the nuclear program is for peaceful purposes.
articles.abstract: Iran has expanded its most sensitive nuclear production site in recent weeks. And for the first time, some leaders are dropping their insistence that the nuclear program is for peaceful purposes.
articles.lead_paragraph: With the rest of the world distracted by wars in Gaza and Ukraine, Iran has moved closer than ever to the ability to produce several nuclear weapons, dramatically bolstering the speed at which it can produce nuclear fuel in recent weeks inside a facility buried so deep that it is all but impervious to bunker-busting bombs.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Farnaz Fassihi

articles.headline: Oklahoma’s State Superintendent Requires Public Schools to Teach the Bible
articles.snippet: The state superintendent, Ryan Walters, said the Bible was a “necessary historical document.” The mandate comes as part of a conservative movement to infuse Christian values in public schools.
articles.abstract: The state superintendent, Ryan Walters, said the Bible was a “necessary historical document.” The mandate comes as part of a conservative movement to infuse Christian values in public schools.
articles.lead_paragraph: Oklahoma’s state superintendent on Thursday directed all public schools to teach the Bible, including the Ten Commandments, in an extraordinary move that blurs the lines between religious instruction and public education.
articles.byline: By Sarah Mervosh and Elizabeth Dias

articles.headline: Why Britain’s Murky Election Betting Scandal Is Causing Outrage
articles.snippet: The embattled Conservative Party is embroiled in investigations over whether some of its own staff members used insider knowledge to bet on the timing of the general election.
articles.abstract: The embattled Conservative Party is embroiled in investigations over whether some of its own staff members used insider knowledge to bet on the timing of the general election.
articles.lead_paragraph: Rishi Sunak’s gamble was a considerable one. Five weeks ago, the British prime minister bet the house on his belief that a summer election might offer his Conservative Party a better chance of holding onto power than waiting until the fall.

articles.headline: The Fed’s Preferred Inflation Measure Cools, Welcome News
articles.snippet: The economy appears to be downshifting and price gains are moderating, as Federal Reserve officials creep closer to beating inflation.
articles.abstract: The economy appears to be downshifting and price gains are moderating, as Federal Reserve officials creep closer to beating inflation.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve’s preferred inflation measure continued to cool as consumer spending grew only moderately, good news for central bankers who have been trying to weigh down demand and wrestle price increases under control.

articles.headline: Justices Limit Power of Federal Agencies, Imperiling an Array of Regulations
articles.snippet: A foundational 1984 decision had required courts to defer to agencies’ reasonable interpretations of ambiguous statutes, underpinning regulations on health care, safety and the environment.
articles.abstract: A foundational 1984 decision had required courts to defer to agencies’ reasonable interpretations of ambiguous statutes, underpinning regulations on health care, safety and the environment.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court on Friday reduced the power of executive agencies by sweeping aside a longstanding legal precedent, endangering countless regulations and transferring power from the executive branch to Congress and the courts.

articles.headline: Supreme Court Says Prosecutors Overstepped With Jan. 6 Charge
articles.snippet: The ruling that the Justice Department misused a 2002 law in charging a pro-Trump rioter who entered the Capitol could have an impact on hundreds of other cases, including one against Donald Trump.
articles.abstract: The ruling that the Justice Department misused a 2002 law in charging a pro-Trump rioter who entered the Capitol could have an impact on hundreds of other cases, including one against Donald Trump.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court ruled on Friday that federal prosecutors had improperly used an obstruction law to prosecute some members of the pro-Trump mob that stormed the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021.
